I think the main failing in many of the discussions I'm seeing here is that they're misstating the question: it isn't do they FEEL pain, it's do they EXPERIENCE pain, like we do.

To explain that difference: we humans have neurons in the spinal chord that can preprocess sensory information and even react to stimuli prior to it reaching the brain, this is helpful as your reaction speed is dramatically increased. For instance if you accidentally touch something hot enough to burn you your spinal chord will reflexively jerk your hand away prior to your brain even receiving the pain signal, i.e. you would react to the pain even if you lacked a brain entirely. Meaning something can feel pain, and react as such, without necessarily experiencing that consciously like we do.

Just to drive it home even more I'll give an analogous example: you could design a robotic system with sensors that detect damage or imminent damage, and program it to react to that in a protective manner. At our current technological level that would be fairly rudimentary and certainly not at the level of conscious experience, it may be as simple even as a temperature/pressure sensor and a motor set to pull the arm away if conditions reached damaging levels. Clearly this simple machine is not experiencing pain, however it would be acting in exactly the same way as if it did.

Therfore the real struggle here is identifying whether or not a lobster is simply feeling pain, or experiencing pain.

Why? Because it's not worth caring about.

For domestic cooks, although the Australian RSPCA suggests lobster distributors be trained in how to professionally kill the animal (expecially to ensure the lobster has been stunned properly, and is more likely to be unconscious for the culling), but as this isn't the case everywhere, in the U.S at least. Some country's have banned the boiling of lobsters with the growing evidence of pain in shellfish. According to the animal welfare charity RSPCA, the most humane way to kill a lobster is-

Stunning the crustacean by chilling it in cold air or cold water shellfish or an ice slurry - saltwater or freshwater, according to the species to not cause shock - for at least 20 minutes

Once the lobster is stunned, it should be mechanically killed as quickly as possible, says the RSPCA, by splitting it along the longitudinal midline on its underside. This can be done without first stunning the animal, but it cannot be considered as entirely humane as it takes even the most experienced person several seconds to carry out

Using the aquatic fish anaesthetic AQUI-S, which studies suggest kills without causing pain or distress (haven't looked into this method but they're claiming it's safe)

The bottom line is that the major concern is not the domestic cook or even restaurant kitchens (Though some are likely guilty of this), but major food processing plants, where animals are commonly dismembered without being killed. Lobsters aren't screaming as you boil them but they are in pain, it's unclear if stunning shellfish renders them unconscious but they become unresponsive to stimuli so may not be alert to feel pain and it is at the very least easier to smoothly out them down.

Not everyone cares their food feels pain, and that's their choice, but I'm trying to provide some more solid information because this comment sections and I at least prefer animals I consume to have a quality life and a clean death personally, I'm not in the position to ensure that until I can lean away from the meat industry but someday.

for small crustaceans (and other small animals in general) being tossed into boiling water is instant death because of their small body size they have comparatively high surface area for their body volume
so the body temperature very quickly exceeds the range in which their proteins are stable
this denatures all their proteins very quickly so their nerves cannot function anymore

Even if you cut into a lobsters head they don’t die immediately. In fact they probably feel just as much if not more pain if they feel any at all. Lobsters don’t have a single centralized brain they have what are called neuroganglia which are like mini brains that operate based off stimuli instead of cognitive function. Humans have them in our spines and they are what cause our reactions and flinching to pain or surprising stimuli. Our brains are what process pain and make us understand “this hurts” lobsters lack that function. The most logical explanation is that lobsters feel stress and stimuli that causes a reaction but they lack the function to actually feel pain. Being numbed would of course turn off the reaction to the stimuli because the body wouldn’t be able to tell anything is wrong. It doesn’t prove lobsters can feel pain. Just that they can’t receive stimuli.

I think it’s not particularly a pain thing but a reaction thing to protect themselves. Like a hand being over a hot stove. You aren’t being hurt but it’s instinctual to pull back your hand because you know if you don’t you will get burned.
They aren’t feeling “pain” but have a natural reaction to start the process of self preservation. If their antennae are irritated, they rub them bc antennae help with their senses. And if you can’t sense anything, you can’t run away from a predator. It’s kinda simplified by that thing that most aquatic animals, particularly fish don’t really have the brain power to REMEMBER pain. They will thrash around and try to protect themselves, and probably get released. But, they will almost always come right back to the same hook less than a few seconds after release. Their “fear” and “pain” thrashing was just fight or flight. Self preservation kicking in. Realizing that a physical injury has occurred so it has to be fixed or protected from the instrument that caused the injury.

I recently saw Humane Hancko's video about fish and how they suffer, and he cited a very interesting study regarding zebra fish. They 2 different tanks that with the same access, one with a "fish park" and one completly bare. The fish clearly showed a preference for the "fish park" and keep going there over the bare one. Them they injected a painful drug to some, they still acted the same. And lastly they put a sustance that alleviated pain in the bare tank, the fishes injected with the painful sustance went to this tank over the "fish park" despite showing a clear preference for that one. Seems pretty likely that not only they could feel pain, they were aware enough to decide to stay in the place that reduced said pain despite liking the other tank better. Very different annimals of course, but while it's harder to have empathy for a lot of sea dweling annimals, the "just in case" aproach is probably for the best.

Pain is the most essential sensation an organism can experience if it even can experience anything at all. For an even mildly complex organism meant to survive in a complex environment, nothing is more essential than a motivational circuitry of pain-pleasure dichotomy as it directs the organism towards doing the things that will result in successful survival and reproduction. Logic is pretty straightforward, and implies every organism that experiences at all, can feel pain. Arguing if the first person experience aspect of the pain is exactly the equivalent sensation we feel is as pointless as asking if my experience of color red is same as your personal experience of color red. If if it isn't, it wouldn't matter from a third person perspective, as all of the causes and effects remain the same. Hence it follows that the aspect of suffering remains the same, even if the experience of pain itself is somehow different, and that's in the end all that matters.

As a Maine native, no one is ever fully under the impression that lobsters don't feel pain. That's something you tell children to make boiling them not send them into a screaming, crying fit. It's an old wives' tale made to numb the realization until they're old enough to fully contextualize. People make their livelihoods on lobster, people who can't just turn over to being software engineers because some California or Washington liberal says so. All food has a price, growing plants effects the environment in lots of equally awful ways if done wrong. The importance is to be sustainable, to be humane and to take the time to make systems for the harvesting of our food that creates a balance between putting food on people's tables and making it so that the animal won't suffer unnaturally at the end.

You will never find a Mainer who doesn't love lobster, not as a food, but as an animal. They're our mascot, our point of pride. We want them to be around for our children's children's children. Making it easy on them at the end with one quick slice is the least we can do for all they've done for us.
